1.text: And Jacob dwelt in the land of Chanaan wherein his father sojourned.

2.text: And these are his generations: Joseph, when he was sixteen years old, was feeding the dock with his brethren, being but a boy: and he was with the sons of and of Zelpha his father’s wives : and he accused his brethren to his father of a most wicked crime.

3.text: Now Israel loved Joseph above all his sons, because he had him in his old age: and he made him a coat of divers colours.

4.text: And his brethren seeing that he was loved by his father, more than all his sons, hated him, and could not speak peaceably to him.

5.text: Now it fell out also that he told his brethren a dream, that he had dreamed: which occasioned them to hate him the more.

6.text: And he said to them: Hear my dream which I dreamed.

7.text: I thought we were binding sheaves in the field: and my sheaf arose as it were, end stood, and your sheaves standing about, bowed down before my sheaf.

8.text: His brethren answered : Shalt thou be our king? or shall we be subject to thy dominion? Therefore this matter of his dreams and words ministered nourishment to their envy and hatred.

9.text: He dreamed also another dream, which he told his brethren, saying: I saw in a dream, as it were the sun, and the moon, and eleven stars worshipping me.

10.text: And when he had told this to his father and brethren, his father rebuked him, and said: What meaneth this dream that thou hast dreamed? shall I and thy mother, and thy brethren worship thee upon the earth?

11.text: His brethren therefore envied him: but his father considered the thing with himself.

12.text: And when his brethren abode in Sichem feeding their father’s docks,

13.text: Israel said to him : Thy brethren feed the sheep in Sichem: come, I will send thee to them. And when he answered:

14.text: I am ready: he said to him: Go, and see if all things be well with thy brethren, and the cattle: and bring me word again what is doing. So being sent from the vale of Hebron, he came to Sichem:

15.text: And a man found him there wandering in the field, and asked what he sought.

16.text: But he answered: I seek my brethren; tell me where they feed the docks.

17.text: And the man said to him: They are departed from this place: for I heard them say: Let us go to Dothain. And Joseph went forward after his brethren, and found them in Dothain.

18.text: And when they saw him afar off, be- fore he came nigh them, they thought to kill him.

19.text: And said one to another: Behold the dreamer cometh.

20.text: Come, let us kill him, and cast him into some old pit : and we will say : Some evil beast hath devoured him: and then it shall appear what his dreams avail him :

21.text: And Ruben hearing this, endeavoured to deliver him out of their hands, end said:

22.text: Do not take away his life, nor shed his blood: but cast him into this pit, that is in the wilderness, and keep your hands harmless: now he said this, being desirous to deliver him out of their hands and to restore him to his father.

23.text: And as soon as he came to his brethren, they forthwith stript him of his outside coat, that was of divers colours:

24.text: And cast him into an old pit, where there was no water.

25.text: And sitting down to eat bread, they saw some Ismaelites on their way coming from Calaad, with their camels, carrying spices, and balm, and myrrh to Egypt.

26.text: And Juda said to his brethren: What will it profit us to kill our brother, and conceal his blood?

27.text: It is better that he be sold to the Ismaelites, and that our hands be not defiled: for he is our brother and our flesh. His brethren agreed to his words.

28.text: And when the Madianite merchants passed by, they drew him out of the pit, and sold him to the Ismaelites, for twenty pieces of silver: and they led him into Egypt.

29.text: And Ruben, returning to the pit, found not the boy:

30.text: And rending his garments he went to his brethren, and said: The boy doth not appear and whither shall I go?

31.text: And they took his coat, and dipped it in the blood of a kid, which they had killed :

32.text: Sending some to carry it to their father, and to say: This we have found: see whether it be thy son’s coat, or not.

33.text: And the father acknowledging it, said: It is my son’s coat, an evil wild beast hath eaten him, a beast hath devoured Joseph.

34.text: And tearing his garments, he put an sackcloth, mourning for his son a long time.

35.text: And alibis children being gathered together to comfort their father in his sorrow, he would not receive comfort, but said: I will go down to my son into hell, mourning. And whilst he continued weeping,

36.text: The Madianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Putiphar, an eunuch of Pharao, captain of the soldiers.
